column1: Will the UN declare that a famine exists in any part of Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, Tanzania, or Uganda in 2020?
column6: ['Health', 'Security and Conflict']
Not going to happen in Tigray, after all. Passage of time.
Famine in other countries, but not in those in the question.
The crowd seems wrong here. There is a small, but not insignificant chance of this happening:
Passage of time

Down on the time frame with regards to the forecast. The drought, floods and locusts could well have been enough to tip the political undercurrents into action, which are not just isolated to Ethiopia, but further afield and as far as Nigeria and Mozambique. Added to all this Covid 19 could well have been the last straw, if ever there was going to be one, and while it has surged in Europe it has not had such a impact on Africa and the Horn of Africa region, and to this point Africa in general

A projection by Fewsnet (Famine Early Warning Systems Network) for October 2020 to January shows an Acute Food Insecurity Phase in East Africa to range from minimal, stressed and crisis which is two steps short (Emergency, Famine) of declaring a famine.

The first consideration for the answer to this question is whether the famine will occur, and only then whether the UN will declare it within the set time frame. And, spoiler alert, my prediction will be based primarily on the assessment of the first part because altogether I don't think the areas will fulfil the requirements of famine and therefore there will be nothing to declare. But all in order:

Another month passes. Decreasing the forecast accordingly but not by very much because the risk of famine is still high. It is the timeline that is unclear. There is likely to be a lag between poor harvests (and other factors) and famine being reported.
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.

Considered the worst locust outbreak in 70 years, there is the potential to leave 5 million people facing starvation. In February the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organisation (FAO) called for $58 million to fund the spraying of insecticide in Ethiopia, Somalia, Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda but a food scarcity issue not a famine. In may scientists warned of a second wave of locusts combined with the Covid-19 pandemic. In June and July, the Famine Early Systems Network were declaring the formation of large swarms of locusts and new hopper bands forming in East Africa and threatening West Africa. At the end of June, the International Rescue Committee stated that a fourth Generation , 8000 times larger than the last was preparing to hatch; hundreds of thousands of hectares have already been destroyed.horised The World Bank has allocated $500 million on top a previous $13.7 million to provide flexible support to control the locust crisis. Covid-19 and the locust crisis have created a situation where a famine has become a likely scenario. The world attention is distracted by domestic Covid problems and economies and the attention required to handle the locust crisis and the appropriate funds may be misdirected to enable an avoidance of a famine.

With increase in inflation, the price of sorghum in Sudan, South Sudan, and similar countries have experienced a 200-250% increase. That could mean heavy food insecurity in this region. The coronavirus has also caused massive unemployment, which means people don't have enough money to afford the increased price for these goods.

Kenya and Uganda currently stable. Somalia and Ethiopia worsening. Cannot find up-to-date data for Tanzania. WFP is increasing assistance—a good sign—but warning of loss of overseas remittances and tourism because of COVID-19 adding a complicating factor (https://www.cbsnews.com/news/coronavirus-famines-united-nations-warning/).

FEWS continues to predict crisis but not famine in the areas we are considering, [1]. The factors others are pointing to are environmental but, regrettably, famine is a consequence of environmental PLUS political factors and the latter are missing in the countries under consideration. (cf. South Sudan and Yemen)

Prediction based upon four sources. The year began with many pre-exisiting indicators that famine is imminent on East Africa & the Horn of Africa.(https://www.worldvision.org/hunger-news-stories/africa-hunger-famine-facts). Now, with locust swarms hitting the region during the planting season (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-84994842-8967-4dfd-9490-10f805de9f68), the outlook is much worse. And the FAO and WFP regional programmes are about to run out of funding with little near-term probability of replenishment. Second generation locust swarms are also forming in the region: an indication that the problem is not under control (see Desert Locust Situation Update 20 June 2020 (http://www.fao.org/ag/locusts/en/info/info/index.html)).

In my opinion the crowd has been overreacting on this question. How would you judge the probability of a famine occuring in either South Sudan, Yemen or Sudan in 2020? Right now I think that P(SS or Y or S) would be somewhere between 60-80% (I'd have to think harder to narrow it down). But now, what's the P(SS and Y and S)? My rough estimate would be 15-35%. Then P(SS and Y and S and Nigeria) would be 1-10%. If we trust FEWS and I do then P(E or K or S or T or U) would be lower than the event I previously mentioned. Besides, how many famines can occur in a year? I guess it would take much more than the present conditions for this to happen. It will be bad, probably worse than year before. Locust will do damage, there will be many people suffering but I feel that a forecast of a famine for this region this year seems like believing a story of some kind of apocalypse ("of biblical proportion") and it might be caused by biased views of Africa caused by the news. I hope and believe they will handle this year's crisis well. As for now I stick with the base rates, disregard premature warnings from the news and the crowd and choose to be optimistic with this question. Also, there have been some important good news this year about the weather which is crucial to the matter. And I don't see any threat of a man-made disaster this year in these countries. “At the end of the day,” Funk says, “humanitarian crises are caused by humans.” An interesting article - https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2020/04/how-team-scientists-studying-drought-helped-build-world-s-leading-famine-prediction If FEWS moves their forecast up I will follow, if someone has arguments against my opinion I'd be glad to hear them.

With lean seasons being from approx. Feb to mid Sept, we should see indications sooner rather than later with diminishing probabilities. Currently and unfortunately, South Sudan is at risk, and not part of the question. My real probability assessment is closer to 40% right now but I'll trust the wisdom of the crowd and inject my own skepticism. That said, I'm comfortable dropping 4% per week from now until Sept. https://fews.net/

Just running a bit of analysis on some data that is available out of Somalia. The average amount of households in the extreme poverty are around 2%. So there would need to be an increase of 18 percent of people in those households to get to the point of famine. I am dropping down about 7 percent due to that fact.

For the UN to declare famine certain criteria have to be met: • At least 20 percent of households in a given area face extreme food shortages with limited ability to cope. • More than 30 percent of children suffer from acute malnutrition. • Hunger causes more than two deaths each day for every 10,000 people. (https://www.worldvision.org/hunger-news-stories/africa-hunger-famine-facts#famine)

Limited food imports, depreciation of local currency, rising cost of food, locust infestation and upcoming drier weather will likely compel UN to declare that a famine exists.

A famine can be declared only when certain measures of mortality, malnutrition and hunger are met. They are: at least 20 per cent of households in an area face extreme food shortages with a limited ability to cope; acute malnutrition rates exceed 30 per cent; and the death rate exceeds two persons per day per 10,000 persons. According to the Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWSNET), none of these countries is projected to be higher than a 3 on the 5-point scale. In today's world, famine is most often caused by conflict. Parts of South Sudan, which has been in a civil war for over six years, are classified as a 4. https://fews.net/

Ordinarily I would say that the base rate likelihood was low and likely to remain so in relatively stable countries but:
Weather, locusts, COVID. 1 in 5 years typically reaches famine status but all these negatives could tip it.

The base rate of famines declared by the UN in the 2010s is 20% (2 in 10 years), 10% if you're restricting this to East Africa alone. Given the anomalous events this year – namely the locust swarms and covid – we've updated this prior by 3.5x. The FEWS predictions suggest that the regions in question are at least 2 phases away from famine.
The base-rate on previous famine declarations on a skim in these countries is ~3 times in the last decade.
recent locust infestation all but guarantees famine

Contributing Factors: COVID-19: There have been few cases of COVID-19 in East Africa, but Kenya has reported one day ago (March 12th) there first known case. The impact of COVID-19 on resources available to aid these countries is unclear, but as COVID-19 presents itself as a global issue it is important to note. However, the implications of a famine declaration will likely push resources up for these countries. (1) - 25% Locusts: The current issue at hand is the locusts in East Africa. Efforts to control the locusts have not worked and major food assistance will be likely needed as conditions that make a famine become more true to the case at hand. (2) Congruently, this is occurring at the beginning of the crop season and will have numerous effects moving forward for many of the countries affected. (3) 50% Famine Conditions: Looking deeper into the dispersion of locusts across already at-risk areas such as South Sudan, Ethiopia, and parts of Kenya, the spread and increase of locust is increasing on an upward trend. (4) 70% Weather: East Africa has seen a drought for quite some time causing the deaths of many people and many people, animals, and crops. This factor alone is determinate of food shortage for quite some time and will need a large amount of improvement to decrease the already increasing food insecurity in the region. (5) 80%

Covid-19 has not yet been reported in any of these countries, but locust have been reported on east coast devestating crops. Not clear what the impact on relief agencies and NGO's covid-19 will have, but operations globally may be impaired. The landing page at https://fews.net/ shows that the listed countries are in Stressed or Crisis conditions, but not yet at famine level. None of the countries are on the Areas of Highest Concern list. Somalia and Ethiopia appear to be most at risk. Weather is likely the biggest factor going forward.
